Issues.Title: perf(ivy): switch ngtsc to use single-file emit
Issues.Body:
In the TypeScript compiler API, emit() can be performed either on a single
ts.SourceFile or on the entire ts.Program simultaneously.

ngtsc previously used whole-program emit, which was convenient to use while
spinning up the project but has a significant drawback: it causes a type
checking operation to occur for the whole program, including .d.ts files.
In large Bazel environments (such as Google's codebase), an ngtsc invocation
can have a few .ts files and thousands of .d.ts inputs. This unwanted type
checking is therefore a significant drain on performance.

This commit switches ngtsc to emit each .ts file individually, avoiding the
unwanted type checking.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "perf(ivy): switch ngtsc to use single-file emit" (#29147)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): generate type references to a default import
Issues.Body:
This commit refactors and expands ngtsc's support for generating imports of
values from imports of types (this is used for example when importing a
class referenced in a type annotation in a constructor).

Previously, this logic handled "import {Foo} from" and "import * as foo
from" style imports, but failed on imports of default values ("import
Foo from"). This commit moves the type-to-value logic to a separate file and
expands it to cover the default import case. Doing this also required
augmenting the ImportManager to track default as well as non-default import
generation. The APIs were made a little cleaner at the same time.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): generate type references to a default import" (#29146)

Issues.Title: fix(bazel): ng build should produce prod bundle
Issues.Body:
`ng build` should produce a bundle that could be readily deployed to
a web server, similar to the behavior of current `ng build` with
webpack.

Note that in Bazel, there is no `ng build` for dev bundles. Instead,
users are expected to run `ts_devserver`.

Closes https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/28877

Issues.Title: IVY doesn't working on Windows even in Angular 8.0.0-beta.7
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package Angular IVY on Windows ### Description I know there was a file path problem in Angular IVY compiler on Windows, but it seems that it has been fixed in Angular 8.0.0-beta.7 (https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/28752) I tried compiling my project with latest version of Angular. ivy-ngcc postinstall script in package.json seem to be working fine. But it still doesn't recognizing the modules of the app and showing below error: `ERROR in Unable to write a reference to MyDirective in D:/MyProject/src/app/shared/my-directive/my-directive.directive.ts from D:/MyProject/src/app/shared/my-directive/my-directive.module.ts` I am following the instructions mentioned in https://next.angular.io/guide/ivy I thought I could be missing something while updating my existing project. So I tried generating a new project using below command: `ng new temp --enableIvy` After generating the project I updated Angular to latest version Angular 8.0.0-beta.7. When running npm install, I can see that after package installation ivy-ngcc postinstall script in package.json seem to be working fine. But when I tried running the build command `ng build --prod`, it threw below error: ``` ERROR in Unable to write a reference to AppComponent in D:/MyProject/src/app/app.component.ts from D:/MyProject/src/app/app.module.ts ``` ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction On windows machine generate a new project: `ng new temp --enableIvy` Update Angular to latest version i.e. Angular 8.0.0-beta.7 Run `npm install` Then run `ng build --prod` ## üî• Exception or Error 

```
ERROR in Unable to write a reference to AppComponent in D:/MyProject/src/app/app.component.ts from D:/MyProject/src/app/app.module.ts
```

Issues.Title: Provide an ability to trigger "saucelabs_tests" CircleCI jobs for PRs
Issues.Body:
Currently "saucelabs_tests" CircleCI jobs are executed every hour for master and patch branches (*not* executed for PRs). In case some PRs break targets in "saucelabs_tests" job, there is no way of verifying the fix, unless it's actually merged into master and the "saucelabs_tests" job runs next time.

It'd be great to have a way of optionally trigger "saucelabs_tests" CircleCI jobs at PR level (for example, by adding a special label), so that the fixes can be verified. It might also be useful for big PRs, to make sure there are no changes that might break CI.

cc @devversion
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Provide an ability to trigger "saucelabs_tests" CircleCI jobs for PRs" (#29137)

Issues.Title: FW-1064 don't modify TNode next pointer when projecting nodes
Issues.Body:
Previously the act of projecting nodes could change connection between `TNodes` (`next` was assigned to point to a next _projected_ node) thus destroying relationship between nodes _before_ content projection. Due to this we were not traverse nodes as they appear in the original template (content nodes before projection). 

This PR introduces the `nextProjected` pointer so we can can track relationship between nodes both _before_ and _after_ projection.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "FW-1064 don't modify TNode next pointer when projecting nodes " (#29130)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): properly detect "inputs" and "outputs" field names that should be wrapped in quotes
Issues.Body:
Prior to this change, the RegExp that was used to check for dashes in field names used "g" (global) flag that retains lastIndex, which might result in skipping some fields that should be wrapped in quotes (since lastIndex advanced beyond the next "-" location). This commit removes this flag and updates the test to make sure there are no regressions.

Issues.Title: feat(platform-server): wait on returned BEFORE_APP_SERIALIZED promises
Issues.Body:
## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

- [ ] Bugfix
- [x] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?

Render does not wait on any returned promises from `BEFORE_APP_SERIALIZED`.

## What is the new behavior?

This update gives external tooling the ability for async providers to
finish resolving before the document is serialized. This is not a
breaking change since render already returns a promise. All returned
promises from `BEFORE_APP_SERIALIZED` providers will wait to be
resolved or rejected. Any rejected promises will only console.warn().

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "feat(platform-server): wait on returned BEFORE_APP_SERIALIZED promises" (#29120)

Issues.Title: refactor(core): static query schematic should handle asynchronous query usages properly
Issues.Body:
With 62157990554306fb76e1e254b31855f966ff65f2, we introduced a schematic
for the Angular core package that automatically migrates unexplicit
query definitions to the explicit query timing (static <-> dynamic).

As the initial foundation was already big enough, it was planned
to come up with a follow-up that handles asynchronous query
usages properly. e.g. queries could be used in Promises,
`setTimeout`, `setInterval`, `requestAnimationFrame` and more, but
the schematic would incorrectly declare these queries as static.

This commit ensures that we properly handle these micro/macro
tasks and don't incorrectly consider queries as static.

The declaration usage visitor should only check the synchronous
control flow and completely ignore any statements within function
like expressions which aren't explicitly executed in a synchronous
way. e.g. IIFE's still work as the function expression is
synchronously invoked.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(core): static query schematic should handle asynchronous query usages properly" (#29133)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): avoid innerHTML usage in exports test (to make it work in IE11)
Issues.Body:
Some tests in exports spec rely on the exact output of innerHTML. In IE11 the order of attributes might change, thus causing tests to fail (in case an element contains more than one attribute). This commit avoids innerHTML usage and performs the necessary checks via element properties.

Issues.Title: test(ivy): fix export tests to work in IE
Issues.Body:
Some of the export tests had assertions that relied on capitalization
of attributes in the DOM. IE treats capitalization somewhat differently,
so our SauceLabs tests were failing.

This commit tweaks the tests so that the assertions do not rely on
attributes to be capitalized or not.

Issues.Title: ci: saucelabs-legacy job should not run schematic core tests
Issues.Body:
With 62157990554306fb76e1e254b31855f966ff65f2 we introduced schematics for `core`, but due to
the fact the Saucelabs legacy job does not run for PRs, we didn't realize
that the legacy Saucelabs job ends up running the schematic specs.

We don't want to run these schematic tests in the legacy-saucelabs job,
as these are node-only specs and the non-Bazel Karma setup is not set
up to provide the devkit schematic node modules.

We exclude the schematics folder in the `core` package in the
legacy-build tsconfig file (similar to how it is done for elements)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "ci: saucelabs-legacy job should not run schematic core tests" (#29124)

Issues.Title: Build of server side bundle is combining to the bundle packages which are linked.
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command ``` - [ ] new - [x] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [x] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Description Build of server side bundle is combining to the bundle packages which are linked (`npm link xyz`). Same package, if is just installed (`npm i xyz`) is just referenced by `require`. This cause a problems with few workflows like auto server side restart by `nodemon`, debugging, ect. It is confusing that build is handling same package in two different ways. Build should handle in same way packages which are under `node_modules`, no matter haw that modules are installed. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. `ng init abc` 2. `cd abc` 3. `npm i uuid @types/uuid` (this is just example of some 3Party package, but it can be any other) 4. create file `src/main-server.ts`: ``` import {v4} from 'uuid'; console.log(v4()); ``` 5. create file `src/tsconfig.server.json`: ``` { "extends": "../tsconfig.json", "compilerOptions": { "outDir": "../out-tsc/server", "module": "commonjs" } } ``` 6. in `angular.json` under the `projects/abc/architect` add: ``` ... "server": { "builder": "@angular-devkit/build-angular:server", "options": { "bundleDependencies": "none", <-- this doesn't help :( "preserveSymlinks": true, "outputPath": "dist/server", "main": "src/main-server.ts", "tsConfig": "src/tsconfig.server.json", "fileReplacements": [ { "replace": "src/environments/environment.ts", "with": "src/environments/environment.prod.ts" } ] } } ... ``` 7. call `ng run abc:server`, generated bundle is 4.55 kB and contains just reference to `uuid` package: ``` /***/ "uuid": /*!***********************!*\ !*** external "uuid" ***! \***********************/ /*! no static exports found */ /***/ (function(module, exports) { module.exports = require("uuid");/***/ }) /******/ }))); ``` 8. now clone the package `git clone https://github.com/kelektiv/node-uuid.git -- node-uuid` 9. link cloned package by `npm link` instde cloned repo 10. under the abc project link uuid package by `npm link uuid` 11. build bundle again by `ng run abc:server`, now bundle size is 11.2 kB and it contains content of linked package ## üåç Your Environment 

Angular CLI: 7.3.4
Node: 10.15.1
OS: win32 x64
Angular: 7.2.7
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router

Issues.Title: feat(@schematics/angular): relocate `ng g service-worker` files
Issues.Body: This is a follow up on https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/13811, with this now all application have the same structure and hence `ng g service-worker` should follow suit and have the same folder structure if generated in a root app, or an app inside the projects.

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/schematics): support unicode character HTML element names
Issues.Body:
The HTML specification allows for a wide variety of characters to be present within a custom element name.  The previous behavior limited the names to mostly alphanumeric characters.  This change opens up the names to include the characters specified within the specification for custom element names.

For example: `app--2root√ü√•` and `app-rootüòÄ` are valid names which work (serve/test) and with AOT.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@angular-devkit/schematics): support unicode character HTML element names" (#13837)

Issues.Title: Architect qol
Issues.Body:
Add a scheduling options to scheduleTarget and Builder on the context so
builders can schedule sub-builds and override the logger.

Add a getTargetOptions() for builders to get access to options from the
host for a specific target. This allows builders to get options, override
some, then scheduleBuilder with those new options, for example.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Architect qol" (#13825)

Issues.Title: Animations are broken on prod AOT build when inheriting styles from base object
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Not that I'm aware of ### Description In an effort to be DRY I have a base style object for some of my more complex animations. Here is a simplified example. ```typescript const baseStyleRed = { backgroundColor: 'red', }; const baseStyleBlue = { backgroundColor: 'blue', }; export const appAnimations = [ trigger('boxTransition', [ state( 'red', style({ ...baseStyleRed, }) ), state( 'blue', style({ ...baseStyleBlue, }), ), transition('blue <=> red', [animate('250ms ease-out')]), ]), ]; ``` Essentially AOT breaks the animation because it doesn't spread the base styles into object passed to the style function. I was able to determine this by looking at the AOT output. I have included a reproduction below. It should switch between a red and blue square and never be green. If it's green then you know the styles for the animation states are not being applied. The issue disappears if you check out the commit before the latest and run the prod build again ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction [Reproduction Repo](https://github.com/adamduren/angular-animation-issue/) [Commit that introduces the bug](https://github.com/adamduren/angular-animation-issue/commit/6ed5395d08ec9a6db8444fb585ead1e3b2d6ffe5) ``` > git clone git@github.com:adamduren/angular-animation-issue.git > cd angular-animation-issue > npm i > npm run build -- --prod > cd dist/angular-animation-issue > npx http-server -p 8000 ``` ## üî• Exception or Error 
N/A
## üåç Your Environment 
Angular CLI: 7.2.4
Node: 10.14.1
OS: darwin x64
Angular: 7.2.7
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router

Package                           Version
-----------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect         0.12.4
@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.12.4
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer   0.12.4
@angular-devkit/build-webpack     0.12.4
@angular-devkit/core              7.2.4
@angular-devkit/schematics        7.2.4
@angular/cli                      7.2.4
@ngtools/webpack                  7.2.4
@schematics/angular               7.2.4
@schematics/update                0.12.4
rxjs                              6.3.3
typescript                        3.2.4
webpack                           4.28.4
**Anything else relevant?** Recent discussion / thoughts on: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/8577

Issues.Title: Incorrect behavior of isBinary util
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report Hi! ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [x] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? No. ### Description I'm trying to generate file from custom schema. I've found incorrect behavior caused by @angular-devkit/schematics/src/rules/utils/is-binary.js This function takes small chunks (24) of file and trying to detect is file binary or not. So if file starts with string contains for example cyrrilic characters, isBinary will return incorrect result (true) because some symbols will be broken after cutting of 24 bits. @schematics/angular/component/index.js Call stack is rootFn => applyTemplates => applyContentTemplate => isBinary I think this lib implements this function more correctly https://github.com/gjtorikian/isBinaryFile ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction I've builded https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/tree/master/packages/schematics/angular/component by tsc and then changed template of component schema (schematics/component/files/__name@dasherize@if-flat__/__name@dasherize__.component.ts.template), added these lines to top (comment block) ``` /** * @overview –Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø–Ø * @copyright Copyright (c) copyright, 2019 */ ``` and then run: ng g c foo ## üî• Exception or Error Template file is not parsed because isBinary returned true, but it is not binary file ## üåç Your Environment 



windows 10
node 10
"@angular-devkit/core": "^7.3.4",
"@angular-devkit/schematics": "^7.3.4",
"@angular/cli": "^7.3.4",
"@types/jasmine": "^3.0.0",
"@types/node": "^8.0.31"

"typescript": "3.2.4"
**Anything else relevant?**

Issues.Title: Revert prettier
Issues.Body: precise-commits' usage of the range options of prettier is not a currently fully support use case for prettier.  The range options appear to be intended to be used with hand-picked ranges at well-defined code borders with an emphasize on performance situations with massive files; and not arbitrary ranges as provided by git commit logs.  This results in errant formatting due to the isolated ranges selected by precise-commits not having sufficient AST context.  There also appears to be an issue regarding partial (ranged) JSON files not being interpreted as JSON.  Further upstream work will be needed to re-integrated precise-commits.  A followup PR may re-introduce prettier on its own as more detailed range support would require a feature addition at the prettier level which would then need to be leveraged by precise-commits.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Revert prettier" (#13823)

Issues.Title: Improve name validation with component schematic (and others)
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [X] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> A clear and concise description of the problem or missing capability...

Using dots in component name when using component schematic (might also happen with other schematics) should fail. I.e. `ng generate component a.b.x` should fail.

I noticed that people who are new to Angular tend to use the schematic like this for the first time:
```sh
ng generate component hello-world.component
```
which produces something funky like this:
```ts
export class HelloWorld.ComponentComponent
```


### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.

Use some whitelist regex to check the component's name before.

By the way, why does the component's selector allow dots in the regular expression below?
https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/eca5dc322f11360b82309c31ed6a716a894fc051/packages/schematics/angular/utility/validation.ts#L20

### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?
```sh
ng generate component hello-world.component
echo D'OH!
git reset --hard
git clean -d -f
ng generate component hello-world
```

Anyway, I am in for a pull request.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Improve name validation with component schematic (and others) " (#13824)

Issues.Title: wrong resolving path
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Description I developed lib which has follow structure -catalogs --src ---lib ----components -----component1 ------component1.component.ts -----component2 ------component2.component.ts -----index.ts ----catalogs.module.ts index.ts in components groups all components into arrays: 
import { Component1 } from "./component1/component1.component";
import { Component2 } from "./component2/component2.component";

export const CatalogsComponents = [ Component1, Component2 ];
The array is used in catalogs.module.ts: 
import { CommonModule } from '@angular/common';
import { FormsModule } from '@angular/forms';
import { CatalogsComponents } from './components';

@NgModule({
  imports: [
    CommonModule,
    FormsModule
  ],
  declarations: [...CatalogsComponents]
})
export class CatalogsModule { }
When I try to build a project I Have a follows exception: projects/catalogs/src/catalogs.ts(7,42): error TS2307: Cannot find module './lib/component1/component1.component'. projects/catalogs/src/catalogs.ts(8,42): error TS2307: Cannot find module './lib/component2/component2.component'. I feel it try to find resolve component paths "./component1/component1.component" "./component2/component2.component" by location of catalogs.module.ts file, not index.ts file. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Create a project as in the bug description. ## üî• Exception or Error 
projects/catalogs/src/catalogs.ts(7,42): error TS2307: Cannot find module './lib/component1/component1.component'.
projects/catalogs/src/catalogs.ts(8,42): error TS2307: Cannot find module './lib/component2/component2.component'.

Issues.Title: distinguising MatRadioGroup change event from DOM change event
Issues.Body:
#### Please describe the feature you would like to request.

MatRadioGroup raises event with a name different from change

#### What is the use-case or motivation for this proposal?

Currently, the only output of MatRadioGroup is (change).
It has the same name as the native DOM event.
If you wrap a <mat-radio-group> outside for example an <input>, then the change event raised by the <input> element will bubble up MadRadioGroup. The handler will be confused, receiving a DOM event without event.source or event.value.

Yes, the handler should check the event object first, but it is a trap for every programmer.

use case: I use a radio group so that user will be filling different part of the form according to the radio button choice. something like only fill in part A when you choose option A, and B B. So I got all sorts of controls inside the radio group.

If MatRadioGroup has used something like sectionChange of MatSelect, then this ambiguity won't happen.


#### Is there anything else we should know?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "distinguising MatRadioGroup change event from DOM change event" (#15409)

Issues.Title: chore: update master to angular version 8 beta
Issues.Body:
This allows us to cherry-pick @kara's static query updates from the
`ivy-2019` branch.

This change includes:
* Adding missing dependencies for various Angular subpackages
* Add umd assets where they are now necessary
* Configure bazel to target ES5 output as a workaround for https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/29107
* Updates most npm dependencies to the @npm// workspace
* Updates general workspace setup, RBE config, ngcontainer
* Update to rxjs 6.4.0 (building from source no longer needed)
* Added rxjs_shims for ts_web_test and ts_devserver targets
* Removed index.bzl and angular_material_setup_workspace (not needed anymore since material won't be built from source)
* Use browser_repositories() from @npm_bazel_karma which have pinned browsers that work on all platforms
* Change dgeni processor functions from arrow function to `function` to
work around `@npm//di` not supporting arrow functions

cc @gregmagolan

Issues.Title: improve support for readonly controls OR improve how to subscribe to form changes with disabled controls
Issues.Body:
#### Please describe the feature you would like to request.
Suggest there be a clean way to either a) get data from disabled controls or alternately b) improve support for readonly controls. Solution is requested in terms of best practices and/or feature enhancements.

#### What is the use-case or motivation for this proposal?
When using a custom component with a form, the form changes need to be watched and emitted to the parent. If the form has values that ought to be readonly, til now I've used the disabled flag *as a workaround* because a) readonly fields have poor visual appearance -- they are not greyed out b) formbuilder supports initializing as disabled, but not initializing as readonly (as shown here https://angular.io/api/forms/FormBuilder#control).

However, when using the workaround, it becomes difficult to watch and emit changes "cleanly" for disabled fields e.g. subscribing to form.valueChanges doesn't get disabled fields, necessitating a duplicative call to getRawValue() after subscribing to changes, to get all the form field data.

#### Is there anything else we should know?
Potential solutions:
a) advise if using readonly attribute is the best practice, rather than using 'disabled' to prevent data entry. If so, hoping there can be some improvements on styling of readonly controls (e.g. they should be greyed out), and also formbuilder should be able to initialize them as readonly. 

b) if angular doesn't intend to support readonly atribute, and instead rely on 'disabled' attribute, then ideally there would be something similar to form.valueChanges that actually gets all form values including disabled controls. 

If (b) is the solution path, then it's low priority admittedly, since it just avoids a little code duplication. I think the core question though is whether there ought to be better support for readonly controls, and if the angular framework intends to maintain a distinction between 'disabled' vs. 'readonly'. 

For my purposes, I mainly disable controls in order to achieve the readonly effect, and then I make a point to getRawValue data so i get all the data. From my research on stackoverflow etc. it appears others do similar workarounds.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "improve support for readonly controls OR improve how to subscribe to form changes with disabled controls" (#15399)

Issues.Title: pre-commit hook code formatting
Issues.Body:
#### Bug, feature request, or proposal:
This project appears to now have a pre-commit hook that runs code formatting on staged files. My question is, **are there plans to run code formatting on the entire codebase in a single PR?** It seems like running code formatting only on staged files will result in much larger diffs associated with each PR. Each PR will contain the changes explicitly made by the contributor as well as a potentially large number of differences that result from code being reformatted. I would think this would make the process of reviewing PR's more difficult.

#### What is the expected behavior?
N/A

#### What is the current behavior?
N/A

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
N/A

Issues.Title: Incorrect position when dragging element inside a boundary
Issues.Body:
#### Bug, feature request, or proposal:

When the child element inside the boundary is selected for the first time, it suddenly jumps on the bottom right of the container.

#### What is the expected behavior?

The selected element should stay at the same position relative to the cursor.

#### What is the current behavior?

It jumps on the bottom right of the container.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?

This file shows an example. If we have a parent container and a child inside with a boundary limited to the parent, the jumping bottom right will occur.

#### What is the use-case or motivation for changing an existing behavior?

In my case this is for an educational mini game.

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?

Angular : 7.2.5,
CDK: 7.3.3,
Browsers: All
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Incorrect position when dragging element inside a boundary" (#15383)

Issues.Title: mat-select options overlay shifted left when first child element is a mat-optgroup
Issues.Body:
#### Bug, feature request, or proposal:
Bug

#### What is the expected behavior?
Options overlay renders at the same position regardless its first child element

#### What is the current behavior?
When a mat-select's first child element is a mat-optgroup (vs a mat-option), the options overlay is shifted to the left. This is more noticeable when combined with a mat-form-field's appearance="outline"

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-hskr5f?file=app%2Fselect-optgroup-example.html

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
Angular 7.2.7
Angular Material 7.3.1
macOS 10.14.3
Chrome 72.0.3626.119
Firefox 65.0.1
Safari 12.0.3
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "mat-select options overlay shifted left when first child element is a mat-optgroup" (#15382)

Issues.Title: mat-table, multiTemplate, matSort: expanding issue after sort
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
After sorting, I expect the row expand when I click on it.

#### What is the current behavior?
The expand action works fine until records are sorted.
After the sort action, and if the row has never been expanded, the expand row appears only after 3 click.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
[StackBlitz Demo](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-material-issue-table-multitemplate-sort?embed=1&file=src/app/app.component.html)
1. Click on a row. The row expands correctly.
2. Sort the records.
3. Click on a never expanded row, the row didn't expand.
4. Click again, the row didn't expand.
4. Click again, the row expands.

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
Angular: 7.2.7
Material: 7.3.3
TypeScript: 3.1.1
Browsers: Google Chrome

#### Is there anything else we should know?
No
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "mat-table, multiTemplate, matSort: expanding issue after sort" (#15380)
